description: Champion Motors is proud to present a wonderful 1965 Jaguar Mark II finished in Opalescent Gold with a red interior. With only 42,387 original miles, this car has been well cared for all its life. The car has never been restored with the exception of a factory color re-spray for its 20th birthday, This Mark II shows just the right patina as it retains all of its original chrome, which has never been replated. The interior is all original with the exception of the front seats and center console, as the past owners wanted to preserve the heritage as much as possible. A true traditional Jaguar it is Right hand drive with a manual 4 speed and an over drive transmission. Under the hood is the respected 3.4 engine, a work horse for an entire generation, as it was used in the D TYPE racing Jaguars for years , winning the LeMans 24 hours no less than 3 times. Stopping the 3.4 this car has factory 4 wheel disc brakes mated to modern radial tires and knock off wire wheels. A complete Falcon stainless steel exhaust and an overriding manual electric choke make this car a pleasure to drive. The boot is complete with the original jack and all the tools supplied inside the tire well. This Jaguar has been recently seen on the new Velocity television show Legends of Design, Astons and Jags."It is a true collectors dream without the hassle of a restoration. Winning many Jaguar Club of North America awards, it received "best driven" in the category at the annual JCNA Concourse. Most service records from England are supplied from 1965 to 1985, accompanied by service records in the states from 1985 to present. Owned by current JCNA member, it is with great pleasure to offer such a car.

Low mileage origional. Been in storage for 5 years. Comes with complete matching parts car. Many spare parts. Ready for minor work to be roadworthy. Drove car from Florida six years ago with no problems.
This 1967 Jaguar XKE Coupe is an excellent original matching numbers Series I car for straightforward restoration. Burgundy with black interior. A great buy at just $56,500
1972 Jaguar XKE Coupe
Two important words to introduce you to our 1972 E-Type Coupe:  One Owner.

This Sable Brown 2+2 Coupe brought us to California in search of this near-perfect example of one of Jaguar's most iconic designs.  Sold to a Dr.who not only loved his Coupe, but did everything right for the next owner by keeping all the ORIGINAL documents including the VIN card and Window Sticker!  Finished in Sable Bown over Cinnamon and outfitted with Automatic Transmission ($269), Air Conditioning ($521), Tinted Glass ($90), Radial-Ply Dunlop Whitewalls ($45), AM/FM Radio Stereo ($235) and Front Bumper Guard ($34), this V12 Coupe was fully loaded in 1972 for $9,301.

Introduced in 1971, the Series 3 E-Type paved the way with an all new V12 .  This incredible powerplant allowed the Jaguar to leap to 60 miles per hour in under 7 seconds – in 1971! Offered primarily with the V12 engine and an Extended Wheelbase, the Series 3 E-Types came as either a Roadster or 2+2 Coupe.

All original ,with the exception of a CD Player installed, this is like traveling back in time to an era when design and driving intersected.  New for the Series 3, the 5.3 litre V12 Engine with 4 Zenith carburetors was originally developed to race in the LeMans series.  Our V12 Coupe starts up without fuss and purrs at idle before growling under full throttle.  All systems work as they should, and the Extended Wheelbase of the V12 body allows for more room throughout the cabin, including the 2 rear seats.  It's not all just looks with this one, as it still pulls very strong and is equally at ease cutting apexes in back roads as cruising along at highway speeds thanks to the stretched proportions of the V12 body.

Stop looking.  Get this one before you miss out and spend the next decade comparing all others to this one ‘that got away' that didn't need anything at all, and came with full documentation.  Trust us – we went to California to get this one!

1967 Jaguar 3..4 saloon; only year for the 3.4; a factory price reduction from the famous 3.8 saloon made for many years; the 3.4 was priced $1000- lower,  came in limited colors; mainly sold on the west Coast and had the older 3.4 proven engine; and came with vynal upholstry Vs. leather as in the 3.8; which also had several more color choices; this model did very well in U.S. sales; dependable and more servicable especially in the california market; cosmetically the same as the 3.8; just priced lower. This particular "rust Free" California model has had a mechanical up-grade utalising a "231" C.I. "Buick" 90 degree even fire V-6 with a modern turbo auto trans; professionally installed,has gorgous two -stage Target red exterior matched to a black vynal interior with red piping; (as original;) wood veneers re-finished; nice original chrome wire wheels; (5) also four wheel power disk brakes;power steering; after-market AM/ FM "Autosounds" radio with remote; new rubber seals, excellent tires; chrome; trim, original restored working gauges and tachometer, solid chassis; under-carrage; and great panel fit. Dependable driver; no maintance issues; sweet!  Original restored 3.8; 3.4 s sell for $40K/60K;; or more; Un-restored examples$15,000-$20,000; (needing Tons of $$ spent!) this is a finished example; more dependable driver then a "Restored" example $22,500.00 (PRICE REDUCTION!!)

Offered for sale, from KURT TANNER MOTORCARS, is this very original and unrestored, low mileage Jaguar E-type. This car was recently purchased from a Jaguar enthusiast from the East Coast who purchased this car from the believed original owner's widow. There is a maintenance sticker still attached to the driver's B-post showing it was serviced on 5-4-73 at 41,550 miles in Winter Park, Florida. The car still retains 3 of it's original Dunlop tires: the two rear tires and the spare tire. They are all matching and correct as factory delivered tires, testament to the car's low original mileage. This car is finished in the fantastic factory color scheme of Opalescent Golden Sand with a Beige interior, a light and elegant color combination for a closed car. The car appears to have had one simple respray at one point, in the same color.

The body on this car is overall excellent, is just about completely rustfree, but has suffered some minor dings and dents from being stored over the years. Panel fit is very good. There is some very minor rust-through on the bottom of both doors. The sills are fantastic. There is only some very minor bubbling down very low on both sides(see picture). The dipped portion of the floors are original and look perfectly fine. Boot floor looks perfect. Overall, a superb body with very little in the way of bodywork or sheetmetal repairs.

The car's interior trim is very original. The carpets have been removed which were falling apart/deteriorated. The car would require a retrim but most all of the items are original to start with. The dashboard facia/gauges/ switches all look excellent. At some point the car's glass was damaged and removed, but is available today both as new and used items.

The car's matching numbers engine has been investigated by the previous owner and no.6 piston is believed to be currently stuck, but is still being soaked with penetrant oil. The oil pan has been removed. The engine compartment is extremely original with lots of original hoses, hose clamps, Lucas battery helmet ends, etc. which would facilitate an easier restoration. All items have been bagged and labelled that were removed from the car. Bonnet fit is very nice with no evidence of accident damage to the nose. Car also includes the original lifting jack with the bag, and pair of original Lucas headlamps.

Overall, a final year Series One 4.2 Liter E-type Coupe in a stunning original color scheme, with very low miles and a matching numbers engine. This car would be a candidate for a perfect high-end Concours restoration. Because of it's solid and straight body and the car's originality, alternatively it could be carefully improved and made into a great road car/driver with some mechanical/cosmetic restoration.  We believe that this car is the finest original, un-restored, "no stories" car currently available on the market for restoration.
Please look at all pictures and call or email with any questions.

1967 Jaguar Mark II Sedan For Sale in Spencer, Indiana 47460

Get ready to turn heads with this 1967 Jaguar Mark II Sedan!  This British Sports Car features a sleek and sporty styling that has become an icon of 1960s motoring. With burgundy paint complimented by an exceptionally clean tan leather interior, this handsome devil will capture the attention of anyone who sees it.  Powered by a newly rebuilt and modified Jaguar 4.2 XK Engine with SU8's engine that is mated with manual transmission, this performance oriented driver offers 205 horsepower.  With only 81,000 miles you can rested assured that this Jaguar Mark II will be turning heads for many years to come.

The Jaguar Mark II is a medium-size saloon car built from late 1959 to 1967 by Jaguar in Coventry, England. The Mark II's body lines, derived from the Mark I, and overall layout proved sufficiently popular over time to provide an inspirational for both the Jaguar S-Type and the Smaller X-type. This 1967 Jaguar Mark has been very well maintained and comes with a plethora of new features that add value to its rich, classic heritage. Some of its highlights include new five speed T5 tranny and clutch, New stainless exhaust, new power rack steering, new disk brakes in front, rebuilt disk brakes in rear, new shocks and bushings, completely restored interior with wood trim redone in England, BMW  535 seats, redone with Connolly leather, sound damping kit and interior sound damping paint, ten speaker sound system, new exterior paint, all chrome redone, all new rubber moldings, finished trunk area, and so much more! This car is in excellent condition and is perfectly suited for anyone who enjoys the rich heritage of classic Jaguars!

This '67 Jaguar Mark II is a must see/drive to truly appreciate its classic authenticity and luster.  In fact, come see for yourself!  You will agree that you cannot find another '67 Jaguar in this condition for the asking price!  Perfect for anyone who collects or appreciates valuable automobile icons.  Don't miss out on this amazing opportunity!  Call today for more information on how you can get behind the wheel of this iconic classic jewel!!!

HISTORY

New seats were fitted which allowed the fitment of head restraints, as required by U.S. law beginning in 1969. The interior and dashboard were also redesigned; rocker switches that met US health and safety regulations were substituted for toggle switches. The dashboard switches also lost their symmetrical layout. SOURCE:  WIKIPEDIA

PLEASE MAKE SURE YOU ARE COMFORTABLE WITH THIS BEFORE BUYING A VINTAGE AUTOMOBILE.  Please call a sales expert to get details on these systems 1-877-422-2940.
CLASSIC CAR RESTORATIONS:

The term "restoration" in context to the vintage car world has taken on a definition of its own. For some people, a restoration is simply painting a car and replacing items as needed, while for others, restoration means an extensive disassembly and overhaul, with each piece getting rebuilt or replaced.

As a consumer, it's important to understand the basics of restoration levels for it can impact classic car values substantially. There are hundreds of ways to “restore” a vintage car or truck including but not limited to the following: i).
Frame off restoration.
Body of vehicle is completely taken off the frame and restoration includes body, frame, floor pans (top and bottom), etc. these restorations tend to be extensive and costly. ii).
Rotisserie restoration.

These restorations are when the body (or body and frame on a unibody vehicle) are disassembled and restored utilizing a rotisserie. Body of vehicle is completely taken off the frame and restoration includes body, frame, floor pans (top and bottom), etc. these restorations tend to be extensive and costly and iii).
Cosmetic or “driver quality” restoration.

These restoration are typically limited to cosmetic items including paint and body, interior, trim and emblems, etc. Within the three levels or restoration mentioned above, there can be varying quality from an “in the garage / amateur” restoration to a high dollar professional “concours” restoration. There is a universal 100 point grading system rating classic car conditions ranging from 100 being excellent to 20 being unrestorable.
In addition to the levels of restoration above, it's important to understand the type of restoration as well for it can also impact value substantially. Type of restorations include: i).
Factory or stock restoration.

This type of restoration is geared towards restoring the car or truck to stock specs from the factory as if it were new. These types of restorations use original or oem (original equipment manufacturer) where possible. Factory original restorations tend to bring the highest dollars from collectors. ii).
Custom restoration.

These types of restorations are geared towards builder preference over factory stock. These can be refereed to as “customs” or “hot rods”. Typically these vehicles will have custom paint work, aftermarket wheels, suspension upgrades, power plant transplants, etc. A specific sector of custom restoration vehicles is “pro-touring” or “restomod / restomods” which are custom built with a more modern street performance and creature comforts than the original factory vehicle.
Please note that WWVA is not a restoration shop nor do we restore vehicles to any degree.
For questions on what type or level of restoration of any of our vehicles in inventory please call our vintage sales expert today at 1-877-422-2940.

We do not recommend driving a classic car home. Many classic cars are not driven often and tend to sit for long periods of time making them unsuitable for cross-country road trips. We strongly recommend shipping the vehicle.

We sell our vehicles mileage-exempt, meaning we do not know the actual, original miles. The information listed in the ad is based on the current odometer reading or from rebuild information provided by the builder, and cannot be used as fact.
Most of these vehicles do not have Carfax or Autocheck history reports; unless the vehicle is 1981 or newer, a Carfax or Autocheck history will not exist.
